properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A deepening Pacific low will make its way across Washington state today. Heavy precipitation will drag the freezing level down to sea level this afternoon. Heavy rain will change over to snow later today. Localized snowfall amounts up to 15 cm are possible depending on precipitation intensity. The heavy precipitation will end this evening as the low moves to the east. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 130 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: tonight and Tuesday morning. Remarks: Winds will generally gust to 100 km/h into this evening, then a bit of a lull is likely for a few hours. Winds will increase again overnight with gusts reaching 130 km/h. Winds will ease upon shifting to southwesterly by midday Tuesday. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major winter storm is expected. A deepening Pacific low will make its way across Washington state during the day then will cross the southeast corner of B.C. tonight. Abundant moisture associated with the system combined with cold air to the north of its trajectory will produce heavy snowfall across the southern interior of British Columbia. Snow will continue over southeastern British Columbia and become heavy this evening before tapering off Tuesday morning. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm is expected for the Kootenays and Elk Valley. For higher elevations and highway passes like Kootenay Pass, amounts of up to 40 cm are possible. Over the southernmost regions, precipitation may briefly change over to rain this evening which will limit the snowfall amounts locally. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-22T12:11:31-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Winter storm to affect southern Manitoba beginning Tuesday morning. Storm total snowfall will be between 10-25 cm by Wednesday evening. A strong low pressure system will track along the international border Tuesday, bringing heavy snow, strong winds, and blowing snow to southern Manitoba. Heavy snow is expected to begin in the southwest Tuesday morning and spread eastward throughout the day and continue into Wednesday morning. A swath of 20-25 cm is likely from Minnedosa eastward to Bissett. In addition to the snow, strong northerly winds, with gusts of 70-80 km/h, will develop with this system throughout Tuesday into the night. This will lead to visibility reductions in blowing snow lasting into Wednesday afternoon. There will also be a risk of freezing rain over areas of Westman south of the Trans-Canada Highway Tuesday afternoon/evening. Conditions will improve from west to east throughout Wednesday as the system departs the province. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-22T13:21:40-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow expected Tuesday afternoon into Wednesday. Snow from a strong low pressure system moving eastward along the US border will spread across Northwestern Ontario Tuesday and continue Tuesday night into Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected across most areas. Locally higher amounts of 20 to 25 cm are also possible in a few localities. Snowfall amounts may be a little lower along the Minnesota Border. Brisk northeasterly winds gusting to 40 or 50 km/h may cause local blowing snow in exposed areas. Driving conditions will quickly deteriorate in the snow beginning Tuesday afternoon. Motorists should consider changing travel plans accordingly. The snow will ease Wednesday afternoon as the low moves away to the east. Snowfall warnings will likely be issued for many areas as this event draws closer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-22T12:46:58-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible for Tuesday night through Wednesday. Snow from a strong low pressure system moving eastward along the US border to Lake Superior will spread across the region beginning Tuesday evening in areas near Lake Nipigon. The snow will spread east to James Bay and the Quebec border on Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible across most areas. Locally higher amounts of 20 to 25 cm are also possible in a few localities. Brisk northeasterly winds gusting to 50 km/h may cause local blowing snow in exposed areas. Driving conditions will quickly deteriorate in the snow beginning Tuesday night. Motorists should consider changing travel plans accordingly. The snow will ease Wednesday night as the low moves away to the east. Snowfall warnings may be issued for many areas as this event draws closer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Winter storm to affect southern Saskatchewan starting Monday night. Storm total snowfall will be between 10-25 cm. A strong low pressure system will track along the international border Monday night bringing heavy snow to much of southern Saskatchewan. Snow will begin in the southwest Monday evening and spread eastward to the Manitoba border by Tuesday morning. A swath of 20-25 cm is expected through Tuesday evening, generally centred between the Trans-Canada and Yellowhead Highways. Along with heavy snow, strong northerly winds of 50 km/h are expected to develop with this system, leading to a visibility reduction in blowing snow. The strong winds will first develop over western sections Tuesday morning and track eastward through the day. There is also a risk of freezing rain over areas near the Trans-Canada Hwy and south toward the international border. Patchy freezing rain will begin over western sections early Tuesday morning and track eastward through the day. Conditions will improve from west to east throughout Tuesday night into Wednesday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-22T13:24:07-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Torrential rain is expected. Total rainfall: 50 to 100 mm, with locally higher amounts possible, especially over higher elevations just inland from the coast. Locations: south coast of Newfoundland from Port aux Basques to the southern Avalon. Time span: continuing until Tuesday evening. Remarks: The heavy rain combined with mild temperatures will also cause any existing higher elevation or inland snowpack to melt, adding to the runoff. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A deepening Pacific low will make its way across Washington state during the day then will cross the southeast corner of British Columbia tonight. Abundant moisture associated with the system combined with cold air to the north of its trajectory will produce heavy snowfall across the southern interior of B.C. Snow will continue across the South Thompson and Shuswap regions this afternoon. Total snowfall amounts will range from 10 to 15 cm before the snow ends tonight. The Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops section will receive 20 cm of snow during the same period. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A deepening Pacific low will make its way across Washington state during the day then will cross the southeast corner of British Columbia tonight. Abundant moisture associated with the system combined with cold air to the north of its trajectory will produce heavy snowfall across the southern interior of B.C. Heavy snow will continue throughout the highway passes today before tapering off late this evening. Total snowfall accumulations will generally range from 25 to 35 cm with amounts up to 40 cm possible near Allison Pass. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Winter storm to affect southern Manitoba beginning Tuesday morning. Storm total snowfall will be between 10-25 cm by Wednesday evening. A strong low pressure system will track along the international border Tuesday, bringing heavy snow, strong winds, and blowing snow to southern Manitoba. Heavy snow is expected to begin in the southwest Tuesday morning and spread eastward throughout the day and continue into Wednesday morning. A swath of 20-25 cm is likely from Minnedosa eastward to Bissett. In addition to the snow, strong northerly winds, with gusts of 70-80 km/h, will develop with this system throughout Tuesday into the night. This will lead to visibility reductions in blowing snow lasting into Wednesday afternoon. There will also be a risk of freezing rain over areas of Westman south of the Trans-Canada Highway Tuesday afternoon/evening. Conditions will improve from west to east throughout Wednesday as the system departs the province. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-22T13:21:40-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 25 to 45 mm. Locations: Labrador Straits. Time span: midnight tonight until midnight Tuesday night. Remarks: A couple of centimetres of snow will likely occur this evening before precipitation changes to rain. The rain will be heavy at times on Tuesday and will combine with mild temperatures to cause significant snowmelt and runoff. Rain is expected to mix with snow Tuesday evening before tapering to scattered flurries near midnight Tuesday night. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard developing tonight at Clyde River and ending early Wednesday. Northwesterly winds will continue to strengthen tonight as a low pressure system over Davis Strait passes by Clyde River. Conditions will deteriorate to blizzard as winds gusting up to 80 km/h develop by midnight accompanied by falling snow. Near zero visibilities are likely throughout the remainder of the night and all of Tuesday. The blizzard will ease early Wednesday morning when the low moves off into Baffin Bay. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

The Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops section will receive 20 cm of snow during the same period. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow expected Tuesday night and Wednesday. Snow from a strong low pressure system moving eastward along the US border will spread across areas north of Lake Superior Tuesday night and continue through Wednesday Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected across most areas with brisk easterly winds helping to keep temperatures below freezing. However there is a possibility that temperatures along the Lake Superior shore may rise a degree or so above freezing by Wednesday morning. If that happens, total snowfall amounts may be limited to less than 10 cm. Brisk easterly winds gusting to 50 km/h may cause local blowing snow in exposed areas. Driving conditions will quickly deteriorate in the snow beginning Tuesday night Motorists should consider changing travel plans accordingly. The snow will ease by Wednesday evening as the low reaches Lake Superior and moves away to the east. Snowfall warnings may be issued as this event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
